thread.title: Icahn launches $150m tax reform super-PAC

title: Icahn launches $150m tax reform super-PAC
text:
Hacks clear path for US cyber bill 
The plan is the only way to halt a wave of multinationals leaving the US in controversial “tax inversion” deals, Mr Icahn said. 
One of Mr Icahn’s largest investments is Apple, which would be a major beneficiary of lower taxes on repatriated earnings, should it wish to bring some of its $150bn-plus overseas cash pile back to the US. 
Similar initiatives have been proposed by the White House and some senior Republicans, but a legislative deal has remained out of reach due to more pressing congressional priorities and disagreements over the details. 
Mr Icahn said he would set up a super-political action committee to use the money to “hold accountable” members of Congress who block a deal. 
Inversion deals — which enable US companies to reduce their American tax bills by being acquired by a foreign business — have been condemned by members of both parties. 
In the latest initiative to deter inversions, a senior Republican and Democrat are in talks on a possible deal to use revenue from international tax reform to fund US highways, but the chances of a bipartisan accord are slim. 
Mr Icahn becomes the latest billionaire to weigh in on US politics with a super-PAC, which he said would seek outside money as well as his own. It would be the first to focus on inversions. 
Thanks to the US Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision, corporations are also allowed to funnel money into political causes through super-PACs. 
In a letter to members of Congress announcing his as-yet-unnamed super-PAC, Mr Icahn wrote: “I promise, the PAC we have started will leave no stone unturned to find out who is most responsible for this ridiculous and unconscionable situation and what can be done about it. The inability of Congress to enact desperately needed legislation because of certain members not willing to compromise is reprehensible, and the members responsible must and will be held accountable.” 
Mr Icahn did not immediately elaborate on how exactly his action committee would put pressure on members to vote in favour of legislation. I promise, the PAC we have started will leave no stone unturned to find out who is most responsible for this ridiculous and unconscionable situation and what can be done about it 
- Carl Icahn 
In the absence of congressional action, the Obama administration tweaked tax rules last year to reduce the attractiveness of inversions. But they have not stemmed the tide and at least five more multibillion-dollar deals have been agreed since then. 
What Mr Icahn called “foundational American companies”, including Pfizer, Walgreens, Monsanto and others, have been considering merger deals with foreign companies, which would allow them to switch domicile and gain access to overseas cash. 
Moody’s calculated that $1.1tn is held offshore by US companies, and Mr Icahn said the number could be twice that. Allowing it to be repatriated and taxed would bring in $200bn, he said. 
Mr Icahn said he would seek meetings with members of Congress in the coming weeks, and warned them that nothing short of US “hegemony” was at stake. Related Topics
